subsection.name: Git the Code
subsection.p: The Force Field X project is hosted at Kenaiwith the source code in a GIT repository. "Gitis a free and open source, distributed version control system designed to handle everything from small to very large projects with speed and efficiency." To clone the Force Field X source first join the Kenai site, set up an ssh key and then join the FFX project. The GIT command is: git clone ssh://KENAI.USER.NAME@git.kenai.com/ffx~source ffx

subsection.name: Building Force Field X
subsection.p: A Maven project file (pom.xml) is provided to build Force Field X on any platform. After cloing the Force Field X git repository, change directoies into the base project directory. Then execute: mvn deploy This requires Maven v. 2.2.1 or later to be installed with its bin directory included in your $PATH environment variable. The first time this command is executed, Maven will download build dependencies and Force Field X runtime dependecies. Future executions are quicker. Force Field X will self-test its modules and report failures. Only code that passes all testing should be uploaded to the Kenai repository, so if any test fails it may be due to a local configuration issue.

Once the build succeeds, Force Field X can be executed using platform dependent start-up scripts located in the bin/PLATFORM directories, where PLATFORM is either macosx, linux or windows. bin/linux/ffxc scripts/energy.ffx The appropriate directory for your operating system may be appended to your $PATH environment variable.

subsection.name: Maven
subsection.p: The Force Field X web site facilitates technology transfer and further development of features and is built with Maven. The Application Programming Interface (API) documentation for Force Field X packages is available as Javadocs. The Force Field X source code is available fully cross-referenced with line numbers. For detailed information on the layout of the Force Field X source code visit the "Project Documentation" area of this website. For example, we use the JDepend Report to avoid cyclic package dependencies.
